reasoning: Cruciality is high because α materially affects whether fixed-compute scenarios imply a hard ceiling on software progress, which in turn shifts governance emphasis (compute controls vs controlling/aligning agentic cognitive labor). Paper-specificity is very high: it directly targets the paper’s explicit simplifying assumption α=0.5 in the CES framing. Tractability is moderate: partial estimates are possible (time-and-compute accounting, ablation-style analyses, retrospective project postmortems, cross-lab comparisons), but mapping real R&D workflows onto a CES ‘task share’ parameter is methodologically difficult, context-dependent, and requires proprietary data. Clarity is fairly strong, though there’s some ambiguity because α in CES is a scale/share parameter, not literally “fraction of tasks,” so an operational definition would need to be fixed to avoid category errors. Decision hook is excellent: it clearly states strategy flips at different α ranges. Dead weight is low; nearly all content supports the question and its stakes.
title: Compute versus cognitive labor share in AI R&D progress
